DOC.HEAD: Bush Congratulates New Romanian President
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday congratulated Romania's new president, Ion Iliescu, and said he was ``amazed and respectful'' of the changes there. The White House said more humanitarian aid is on the way. ``My concern is for tranquility and freedom in Romania,'' Bush said at an airport news conference here as he began a six-day hunting and fishing vacation. At the same time, he declined to criticize harshly the quick executions of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife. ``We did say that we were concerned that the trial of Ceausescu should have been more open, but that's their matter,'' Bush said. He said he was ``just amazed and respectful of the change that has taken place'' in the final hardline East bloc nation to undergo democratic upheaval. The president said he was especially ``touched'' at hearing about a Christmas carol being sung on the state-run television for the first time in 40 years. ``It made a dramatic statement to me,'' Bush said. Bush said the army appeared to be restoring stability in the violence-torn country. Bush also sent a congratulatory message to Iliescu. ``The president expressed his sympathy over the tragic bloodshed during the past two weeks and his hope that Romania will now move along on a peaceful path of democratic change,'' the vacation White House said in a statement. In his message, Bush ``expressed the hope that the new Romanian government will move quickly to implement democratic reforms based on the rule of law.'' ``He pledged U.S. support and assistance as Romania meets these challenges during the difficult transition ahead.'' The administration was sending a C-141 cargo plane loaded with medical supplies from West Germany to Romania on Thursday, the Agency for International Development (AID) said. The cost of the flight and supplies, about $250,000, was in addition to the $500,000 in cash the administration was giving to the International Red Cross for medical supplies and other humanitarian aid, and $25,000 from an embassy contingency fund in Romania. AID also said a team of experts from Washington was to arrive in Romania Thursday ``to assess humanitarian needs to distribute the relief flight's cargo.'' At the State Department, spokesman Mark Dillen said the U.S. ambassador to Bucharest, Alan Green, had requested an appointment with the provisional president, Ion Iliescu, but no appointment had been scheduled. Commenting on reports of an anti-Communist rally in the Romanian capital, Dillen said the embassy had said the demonstration was attended by 500 to 1,000 students and that a student leader had appeared on Romanian television. ``We encourage the government of Romania to allow all voices to be heard as the process of reform and the transition to a new government progresses,'' said Dillen, reading a prepared statement.
